topics.name: Logs
topics.subtitle: How long do they keep them?
topics.title: Logs

tosdr.tldr: Google collects a lot of information about the services you use and how you use them, including searches, personally identifiable information and activity when you visit a website using a Google service (e.g. via search or an advertisement). Google does not disclose how long this information is kept on their servers.

points.title: Google retains rights on your content when you leave

topics.description: Once you subscribe to the service, will you have the right to leave it and remove your data?

topics.name: Right to leave the service
topics.subtitle: To avoid lock-in and stay in control
topics.title: Right to leave the service

tosdr.tldr: The copyright licence that you grant to Google on content you upload to their services continues even if you stop using the services. This licence applies to all Google services due to their universal terms across services. Otherwise you need to check each service for ways to remove content and for specific clauses that restrict the license in time.

topics.name: Jurisdiction and governing laws
topics.subtitle: Where can you sue, or be sued, for breaching of the rules?
topics.title: Jurisdiction and governing laws

tosdr.case: court of law is in location X
tosdr.tldr: This terms of services agreement is governed by the laws of California, USA, excluding California's conflict of laws rules. This means if there's a dispute between you and Google about the terms of service, you have both already consented to personal jurisdiction in the federal or state courts of Santa Clara County, California.

topics.name: Law and government requests
topics.subtitle: How do services deal with government requests?
topics.title: Law and government requests

topics.description: The terms sometimes describe the level of logging and the level of data collection and which kinds of data the service is processing. Anonymity or the right to use a pseudonym can be very important for freedom of expression (e.g. for people exercising a certain profession, or people living in authoritarian regimes).

tosdr.tldr: Google can share your personal information with other parties. For sensitive information (medical, racial, ethnic, political, religious or sexuality) Google requires your "opt-in" consent. Google can also share or publish aggregated data that does not identify you.

points.title: Google can use your content for all their existing and future services

topics.description: The content and the data you generate on services online is usually subject to copyright law. When your data are collected by services, they can be considered personal data.  It means that it is your content, your data: you can decide.

example.bad: We get a license beyond the requirements to operate the service, so your data may be used for purposes you do not intend. We will still attribute ownership to you.
example.blocker: We become the owners of your data.
example.good: You license us to use your data only for the purpose of operating this service.

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.name: Ownership
topics.subtitle: What happens with the content you generate on the service?
topics.title: Ownership

tosdr.case: they can use your content for all their existing and future services
tosdr.tldr: The content you post on a particular Google service can be used by Google on other services you may not be aware of, and even with future services that have not been created yet.

To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.description: Services need to evolve. But it is important that updating the service does not break the consentment with the user. Updates and changes to terms of service and privacy policy need to be properly noticed to users and to sollicit their agreement again.

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.name: Notice of Changing Terms
topics.subtitle: Are users notified when terms change? Are they given enough time to find out what changed and discuss this with each other before deciding whether to continue to use the service under the new terms?
topics.title: Notice of Changing Terms

tosdr.case: user is notified a week or more in advance
tosdr.tldr: Ordinarily, Google posts changes to terms on their site or if they are significant, will notify you via email. Google won't implement changes sooner than 14 days after noticed was given or posted. They will not reduce your rights under their privacy policy without your explicit consent.

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.description: Copyright law gives you control over how your content (texts, photos, videos, etc.) can be used, by whom they can be distributed, modified, etc. Sometimes, online services need your permission to perform certain tasks with your content. That's why they ask you to grant them a copyright license. But sometimes, the copyright license is so broad, that your content can be exploited by others without asking you.

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.name: Scope of the copyright license
topics.subtitle: Do you grant only the necessary rights?
topics.title: Scope of the copyright license

tosdr.case: limited for purpose across broad platform
tosdr.tldr: The copyright license you grant Google is limited to the purpose of operating, promoting, and improving their services, and to develop new ones. It is not however limited by time - so if you leave the service, Google retains the rights to use your content for these purposes.

points.title: Google may stop providing services to you at any time

topics.description: Your account and your data are on their servers, so they control them. Which guarantee do you have that lawful content and lawful activity will not be censored or suspended?

topics.name: Suspension and Censorship
topics.subtitle: Can they end your use of the service at any time?
topics.title: Suspension and Censorship

tosdr.case: they may stop providing the service at any time
tosdr.tldr: "Google may stop providing services to you, or add or create new limits to services at any time." Google has no obligation to give you advance notice or to give a reason for that termination.

points.title: You can export your information before a service is discontinued

topics.description: The content and the data you generate on services online is usually subject to copyright law. When your data are collected by services, they can be considered personal data.  It means that it is your content, your data: you can decide.

example.bad: We get a license beyond the requirements to operate the service, so your data may be used for purposes you do not intend. We will still attribute ownership to you.
example.blocker: We become the owners of your data.
example.good: You license us to use your data only for the purpose of operating this service.

topics.name: Ownership
topics.subtitle: What happens with the content you generate on the service?
topics.title: Ownership

tosdr.case: they provide a way to export your data
tosdr.tldr: When a service is discontinued for all users, Google gives you reasonable advance notice so you have an opportunity to export your information from that service.

points.title: This service tracks you on other websites

topics.description: Cookies are files stored locally in your web browser containing identifiable information.

To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.name: Cookies
topics.subtitle: and related technologies
topics.title: Cookies

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

tosdr.tldr: This service and their partners use cookies to track you even if you are not interacting with the service directly. Information gathered about you could include: date and time you visit the site; the web address or URL you're on; technical information about the IP address, browser and the operating system you use; and, if you are logged in to the service at the same time, your user ID.
